title: Faith, Hope, and the Five Wise Men's Journey
content:
# Faith, Hope, and the Five Wise Men's Journey

## The Call to Let Go

Faith and hope are not passive states of mind—they are active forces that guide us, but only if we are willing to let go.  
Imagine a child crying early in the morning because they don’t want to go to school. The child sobs, “No, I don’t want to go. Please don’t leave me. These people will eat me!” But the mother, with a firm heart, says, “No, you have to go. You must.”  

That child’s resistance is a lot like our own when life asks us to step into the unknown. We cling to comfort, to the familiar, even when it no longer serves us. But just as the mother must strengthen her heart to let her child go for a few hours so the child can grow and learn, we too must sometimes release what we hold dear—even when it feels safe, even when it’s all we know.  

There is a profound difference between being *complacent* and being *content*.  
Complacency says, “I’m comfortable, but I still complain. I want more, but I won’t move.”  
Contentment says, “I am happy with what I have, but I continue to work for more.”  
The grapes may seem sour when we don’t move—but when we act with hope, we taste their sweetness.

## The Path to Awakening

According to the wisdom of Krishna, true awakening happens when we stop living only for ourselves—when the small emotions of jealousy, anger, and passion no longer grip us repeatedly. It’s the moment we become aware of a feeling as it arises in our consciousness, and, even more importantly, when we realize that there are many truths.  

As long as I believe there is only one way, I am bound to become rigid. If I think my way is the only right way, it’s natural that I’ll become inflexible in my perspective. Believing I’m right is one thing—believing *only I* am right is something else entirely. The first may be conviction; the second is tragic. On the spiritual path, thinking “only I am right” is deadly.

## The Parable of the Five Wise Men

Once, five wise men were traveling together through a dense forest. In the middle of their journey, they lost their way. Fear set in—who knew what dangers lay ahead: bears, tigers, the unknown?  
They stopped and debated what to do.

The first said, “Let’s go left. The word ‘left’ itself implies separation—we must go that way.”  
The others disagreed. “No, not left. If you wish, you may go, but we will not.”  
So the first man went left, confident he knew the way.

The second declared, “It’s obvious—we must go *right*. The word ‘right’ contains truth, righteousness. It is correct.”  
Still, the others were unconvinced. “You may go, but we are not sure.”  
So the second went to the right.

The third, pragmatic and bold, said, “You’re all wrong. Don’t go anywhere yet.”  
He climbed a tall tree to see the path from above. From that height, he could see the way clearly.

The fourth announced, “I’m going straight. Courageous people never look back—they move forward with directness. Straight is the only way.”  
The man in the tree shouted down, “But there *is* no straight path! I don’t see one!”  
The fourth replied, “You can’t see everything. There may not be a metal road, but I’m going anyway.”  
And he went straight ahead.

The fifth shook his head. “You are all ignorant, arrogant fools,” he said. “It’s perfectly clear—we must go back. We should return to our city.”  
No one listened. They called him a coward.  
So he turned back.

The man in the tree watched them go, thinking, “These people are truly foolish. They will die terrible deaths. But I am here. I know the way. When morning comes, I’ll help myself—and maybe I’ll find their bodies along the way, or at least one of their friends.”

But he was wrong.  
He was not the wisest of the five.

## Why They Were All Right

In time, each of the five arrived somewhere meaningful—just not the same place.

- The one who went **straight** got stuck in a swamp. There, he learned to survive. He discovered ways to live in the wild, and later taught those skills to others lost in the forest.
- The one who went **left** reached a different town. He helped build a road into the forest so others could safely bring back wood and resources.
- The one who went **right** arrived in a new village. There, he learned a new trade, met new people, and built a new life.
- The one who went **back** returned to his city and said, “I will build a safe road into the forest so no one gets lost again.”
- And the one who **climbed the tree** became a preacher. “I can help you,” he said. “I see the way. I have an aerial view, like the Buddha. I know the path.”

Each of them ended up in a different place, at a different turn in life.  
And each was right.

## The Lesson of Many Paths

Whenever you begin a new journey, this is the only thing worth remembering:  
**Have faith. Have hope. It will take you somewhere—but only if you are willing to let go.**

If you are like the child who cries every morning because they don’t want to go to school, remember: that is your preschool. Life is saying, “You must go.”  
You have to strengthen your heart to release what you love, so you can grow.

Emily Dickinson wrote:  
> “Hope” is the thing with feathers—  
> That perches in the soul—  
> And sings the tune without the words—  
> And never stops—at all—

Hope asks nothing of you. It only gives.  
In the coldest lands and strangest seas, it sings—and never, in extremity, asked a crumb of me.

## Trusting the Intelligence of the Universe

When you feel discouraged, stuck, or afraid—when you wonder, “How will I do this? What will happen?”—remember that life moves on its own.  
You only need to trust the intelligence of the universe.  
Have faith in a power—whatever you name it—and know that all shall be well. This is not the end of the world, nor is it the end of yours.

In the Bhagavad Gita, Krishna tells Arjuna:  
> When all fails, go to the Divine. When nothing works, why not take refuge in that?  
> I have now told you everything. Do as you wish.

You cannot live a static life.  
Everything is constantly changing.  
If you accept your own transformation and understand that there are many paths to satisfaction, fulfillment, and peace, then every moment—every step—becomes enlightening. It becomes a joyful moment, not a constant suffering until death.

Krishna called those who cannot stop worrying about the future “demonic in nature.”  
That is not the sign of a wise person.  
It is not the sign of someone who has faith.

## The Practice of Surrender

You must work with all your capacity toward what you know—and then rest. You must surrender it.  
When we go to sleep, we may check the locks and doors, but we don’t say, “What if I forget to breathe?”  
We surrender that to something else.  
Nature has a way of keeping you alive.  
If you try to hold your breath longer than your body can bear, you will faint—and breathing will begin again.

Nature also has a way of keeping your mind and dreams alive—so long as you don’t kill them, but nurture them.  
And nurturing requires meditation, mindfulness, faith, and also acceptance.

So when doubt arises, when the path is unclear, remember the five wise men.  
Each found his way.  
Each was right.  
And so, in time, will you.
